bestBHT.bht: Worse must come before all is over - earthquakes, famines, pestilences, and terrifying sights and terrors. These woes are characterized by a play on words, with famines and pestilences and terrors pronounced alike in the Greek. The word terrors is a rare one, denoting fright. Josephus elaborates on these signs, mentioning great earthquakes and fearful sights and signs from heaven, including comets and blazing stars.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: must come before all is over.
Archibald T. Robertson: Famines and pestilences (λοιμο κα λιμο). Play on the two words pronounced just alike in the Koine (itacism).
And terrors (φοβηθρα τε). The use of τε ... τε in this verse groups the two kinds of woes.
This rare word φοβηθρα is only here in the N.T. It is from φοβεω, to frighten, and occurs only in the plural as here.
John Gill: And great earthquakes shall be in divers places, and famines and pestilences...
Fearful sights...terrible things...dreadful thunderings, and lightnings...
Great signs shall there be from heaven...comets and blazing stars, a flaming sword...
John Wesley: Fearful sights and signs from heaven — Of which Josephus gives a circumstantial account.

bhtAttempts.bht: Worse must come before all is over - earthquakes, famines, pestilences, and terrifying sights and terrors. These woes are characterized by a play on words, with famines and pestilences and terrors pronounced alike in the Greek. The word terrors is a rare one, denoting fright. These events are not to terrify us, but rather serve as signs and warnings. Josephus further elaborates on these signs, mentioning great earthquakes, fearful sights and signs from heaven, and even comets and blazing stars.
